results.title: Behind the scenes at Walt Disney studios
results.creator_credit: Alfred L Werker, Hamilton Luske and Walt Disney
results.brief_description: Humorist Robert Benchley visits the Disney Studios to sell Walt on the idea of animating the story of The Reluctant Dragon. While evading an officious young studio guide, Benchley stumbles into various studio activities and departments, including an art class, a sound effects session, the multiplane camera studio (at which point he notices the film has switched to Technicolor), the paint lab, a storyboard session for the “Baby Weems” segment, a movieola screening of the Goofy cartoon “How to Ride a Horse”, and finally catches up with Walt in a screening room just as he’s previewing the studio’s latest film… The Reluctant Dragon! Cinematography by Bert Glennon and Winton C. Hock. Edited by Paul Weatherwax.

results.title: Behind the menu
results.brief_description: A warning against unsanitary conditions in restaurants, and a demonstration of precautions that should be taken against dirt and harmful bacteria in the handling of food. Suggestions are made for increasing efficiency through better food storage, dishwashing methods and staff facilities. Measures taken by public health authorities to maintain standards in restaurants.

results.title: Behind the mask
results.creator_credit: Kim Farrant, AFTRS and Kate Riedl
results.brief_description: Behind the Mask reveals the complex emotions and identities of a group of young Melbourne primary school students. The ancient art of mask making provides a dramatic ritual which acts as a catalyst for self expression, revealing deep rooted feelings and thoughts, not usually associated with 10 and 11 year olds. By creating their own masks and performing with it in front of their peers and parents, the children find a voice to express the complex emotions and concerns that effect their lives. An extremely powerful and revealing program about children’s experience of life.

results.title: Behind the airline
results.creator_credit: Frank Coffey, H.G. Guinness, Movietonenews and Qantas Empire Airways
results.brief_description: December 1953 was the 50th anniversary of heavier than air flight. This film compares the early flights by the Wright Brothers in America and W.E. Hart in Australia, with the highly complex organization of a modern international airline in Australia. The film illustrates the many activities of airline personnel, all of whom play their part in keeping aircraft in the air. Commentary by Harry Dearth, photography by Syd Wood.

results.title: Behaviour patterns and survival
results.brief_description: Depicts the behaviour of the Slaty Backed Gull. Types of chick behaviour, innate and learned are shown by response to parent’s voice. Originally in Japanese - dubbed into English. Suitable for Mid-Upper Secondary level students.

results.title: Beginnings of vertebrate life
results.creator_credit: William Kay and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Reveals complex processes by which a one-celled egg, becomes a many-celled, highly organized individual. Shows by means of time-lapse photography and animation the embryonic development of a small fresh water fish, Oryzias latipes, illustrating early processes of fertilization, cell division and formation of the blastula.

results.title: Beginnings - Inspiration - the Role of the Writer
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Writers on Writing”.
This series is based on a growing archive of video material of conversations between contemporary writers discussing their work. The material has been re-edited to form a resource for students and teachers of English, and each of the six twenty-minute videos focuses on different aspects and stages of the writing process. Each video is accompanied by a resource booklet. In this video, writers talk about how they began to write, what their inspiration is and their perception of the writer’s role.

results.title: Beginning wheel techniques
results.brief_description: An introduction to the fundamentals of pottery. Wheel throwing is simplified by using the clock dial as a means of reference. Techniques shown making a cylinder are sticking, mastering, centering, opening, raising and finishing. The potter’s rib is demonstrated. The needle point tool is used to level and to test for centre bottom thickness. Similar techniques are shown for bowl and plate forms.

results.title: Beginning tumbling
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tumbling”.
By regular and slow-motion demonstration, accompanied by a simple explanatory commentary, the following tumbling starts are taught: forward roll, dive to forward roll, three men sideward roll, stand, hand walk, cartwheel, round-off and combinations.
